thread.title: Uber, Didi Kuaidi seek to legalize status in China
thread.title_full: Uber, Didi Kuaidi seek to legalize status in China | Reuters

author: Reuters
title: Uber, Didi Kuaidi seek to legalize status in China
text:
SHANGHAI U.S. firm Uber Technologies Inc [UBER.UL] and Chinese rival Didi Kuaidi are taking steps to operate legally in China, a key market for both firms but where their car hailing services currently operate in a regulatory prey zone.
Uber China said in a statement on Thursday it was "actively preparing" documents to apply for a license to operate an online car-hailing platform to meet new regulations governing the sector that are expected to be announced soon.
Didi Kuaidi, a $16 billion valued firm backed by Chinese Internet giants Alibaba Group Holding Ltd ( BABA.N ) and Tencent Holdings Ltd ( 0700.HK ), also said on Thursday it had received a car booking license for its operations in Shanghai and that it was seeking more licenses from other cities.
"This license is a key milestone for the official recognition and the legal status of private car-hailing services in China," Didi Kuaidi said in the statement.
Uber and Didi Kuaidi are locked in a turf war in China, investing billions of dollars to lure in riders with steep discounts and to subsidize the money earned by drivers.
But like in many countries across the world, the legality of these car hailing services has vexed regulators in China where the authorities say drivers who lack the proper licenses are operating outside the law.
Didi Kuaidi is the dominant ride-hailing app in China, although Uber recently closed a $1.2 billion deal to enter 100 more Chinese cities in the next 12 months.
(Reporting by Adam Jourdan; Editing by Miral Fahmy )
